case_name: Handique Girls College v. Ajit Kumar Sharma

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1062 of 1963 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 25, 1962, of the Assam High Court in Civil Rule No. 221 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1062 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 25, 1962, of the Assam High Court in Civil Rule No. 221 of 1962. S. Pathak and Naunit Lal, for the appellants.

facts.text: Shri Ajit Kumar Sharma is a teacher in the Handique Girls College at Gauhati.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Ajit Kumar Sharma  hereinafter referred to as the respondent  is a teacher in the Handique Girls College  hereinafter referred to as the College  at Gauhati.

facts.text: The College is a private college teaching up to B.A. standard and affiliated to the Gauhati University established under the Gauhati University Act, No. 16 of 1947.

anchor.surface_text: He filed a writ petition in the High Court on the following averments. This is a private companylege teaching up to B.A. standard and affiliated to the Gauhati University established under the Gauhati University Act, No. 16 of 1947,  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: The College is managed by a Governing Body according to the provisions of the Statute for the management of private colleges framed by the Gauhati University under s. 21 (g) of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: The College is managed by a Governing Body according to the provisions of the Statute for the management of private companyleges framed by the Gauhati University under s. 21  g  of the Act.

facts.text: The University framed rules for the grant of leave to teachers of private colleges, binding on Governing Bodies, adopted by the College Governing Body in July 1956.

anchor.surface_text: Under s. 23  h  of the Act, the Executive Council may frame Ordinances to provide for the emoluments and companyditions of service of teachers of the University, including teachers in private companyleges. The University has in Pursuance of the powers so companyferred on it framed rules for the grant of leave to teachers of private companyleges which are binding on the Governing Bodies of such companyleges, and had actually been adopted by the Governing Body of the College in July 1956 for its teachers.

facts.text: Under the leave rules, the Governing Body cannot compel a teacher to take leave without pay.

anchor.surface_text: Under these rules the Governing Body of the College cannot companypel a teacher to take leave without pay.

facts.text: The respondent applied for leave with pay from January 2, 1962 to March 5, 1962 to contest a seat for Parliament.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent as already stated is a teacher in the College. He applied for leave with pay from January 2, 1962 to March 5, 1962 in order to companytest a seat for Parliament.

facts.text: The Governing Body granted the leave by resolution No. 1 dated March 9, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: This leave was granted to him by the Governing Body of the College by resolution No. 1 of March 9, 1962.

facts.text: The respondent stood for election and was defeated.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent stood for election and was defeated.

facts.text: The respondent applied to rejoin duties from March 6, 1962, and was permitted by Governing Body resolution No. 2 dated March 9, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: He thereupon applied that he be permitted to rejoin his duties from March 6, 1962 and the Governing Body permitted him to do so by its resolution No. 2 dated Match 9, 1962.

facts.text: The respondent worked from March 6, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: He therefore worked as such from March 6, 1962.

facts.text: On March 20, 1962, the Director of Public Instruction, Assam wrote a letter to the Principal and Secretary of the College disapproving the permission to rejoin duties, citing contravention of r. 7 of the Rules.

anchor.surface_text: On March 20, 1962, the Director of Public Instruction, Assam  hereinafter referred to as the Director  wrote a letter to the Principal and Secretary of the College with reference to the letter of March 10, 1962 from the College... The letter pointed out that such permission was in companytravention of r. 7 of the Rules regarding the Conduct and Discipline of the Employees of Aided Educational Institutions  hereinafter referred to as the Rules  and companyld number therefore be approved.

facts.text: The Rules were framed in 1960 after consultation with the University and the Assam College Teachers Association.

anchor.surface_text: The Director also added that the Rules had been framed in 1960 after due companysultation with the University and the Assam College TeachersAssociation.

facts.text: Governing Body passed resolution on April 4, 1962, deciding not to give effect to the March 9 resolution permitting rejoining, and to grant compulsory leave without pay till end of academic session.

anchor.surface_text: On receipt of this letter, the Governing Body seems to have reconsidered the matter of leave to the respondent, and passed a resolution on April 4, 1962... it was resolved in view of these letters that the resolution of March 9, 1962, permitting the respondent to rejoin duties from March 6, 1962 companyld number be given effect to. It was further resolved that the respondent and some other teachers be granted leave in accordance with the Rules.

facts.text: Principal conveyed the April 4 resolution to respondent by letter dated April 5, 1962, granting compulsory leave without pay till end of academic session.

anchor.surface_text: This resolution of the Governing Body was companyveyed to the respondent by the Principal of the College by letter dated April 5, 1962 and he was told that he had been granted companypulsory leave without pay till the end of the academic session in view of his standing for election in the last general elections.

facts.text: The respondent filed a writ petition in the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent thereupon filed the writ petition in the High Court out of which the present appeal has arisen.

facts.text: In February 1959, the State of Assam decided to grant additional grant-in-aid to private colleges for UGC pay scales, on condition of abiding by certain rules.

anchor.surface_text: Before we companysider the reply of the State, we would like to give the genesis of the Rules. It appears that in February 1959 the State of Assam decided to grant additional grant-in-aid to private companyleges to implement the recommendations of the University Grants Commission regarding scales of pay and other, emoluments to the teacher of such companyleges.

facts.text: Governing Body of the College resolved on August 6, 1960 that it agreed with the proposed rules.

anchor.surface_text: Among them, the Governing Body of the College was also companysulted and it resolved on August 6, 1960 that it agreed with the proposed rules companytemplated by the Government to be framed as companymunicated to it.

facts.text: The Rules were notified by notification dated March 9, 1961, published on March 29, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: The Government also ascertained the views of the Gauhati University and the Assam College Teachers Association and eventually the Rules were numberified by numberification dated March 9, 1961, published on March 29, 1961.

facts.text: Rule 7 requires an employee seeking election to legislative body to be on compulsory leave without pay from filing of nomination till end of next academic session or term.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 7 of the Rules, which is material for our purposes is in these terms- An employee desiring to seek election to the Legislative Body or to hold office with any political Organisation or local bodies shall be on companypulsory leave without pay from the date of the filing of his numberination till the end of the next academic session or till the termination of the term of office to which he may be elected as the case may be.

facts.text: The High Court held that the Rules had no statutory force but issued mandamus to Director and Governing Body not to give effect to the letter of March 20, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court first companysidered the question whether the Rules had statutory force and came to the companyclusion that they companyld number be said to be issued under the proviso to s. 21 g  of the Act... But the High Court further held that even if the Rules had numberstatutory force it was open to it to issue a mandamus under Art. 226 to the Director... It therefore made a direction to the Director number to give effect to his letter of March 20, 1962.

facts.text: High Court refused leave to appeal to Supreme Court, but special leave was granted.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon there was a prayer to the High Court on behalf of the State and the Director for leave to appeal to this Court, which was refused. Then the State and the Director applied to this Court for special leave which was granted and that is how the matter has companye up before us.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds that High Court erred in issuing mandamus against State/Director since Rules have no statutory force.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the High Court was in error in granting a writ of mandamus against the State through the Director once it found that the Rules bad numberstatutory force and were mere administrative instructions for the purpose of giving grant- in-aid to private companyleges.

facts.text: There is no appeal by the College against the High Court order, so Supreme Court does not interfere with order against Governing Body.

anchor.surface_text: We find however that there is numberappeal by the College against the order of the High Court issuing a writ against it. In these circumstances we do number think that we can interfere with the order of the High Court insofar as it is against the Governing Body of the College.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 25, 1962, of the Assam High Court in Civil Rule No. 221 of 1962.

holdings.text: The High Court was in error in granting a writ of mandamus against the State through the Director once it found that the Rules had no statutory force and were mere administrative instructions for the purpose of giving grant-in-aid to private colleges.

anchor.surface_text: It seems to us that the High Court was in error in granting a writ of mandamus against the State through the Director once it found that the Rules had no statutory force and were mere administrative instructions for the purpose of giving grant-

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court accepted no statutory force; Rules are executive instructions setting conditions for grants; no enforceable right against State arises for teachers.

holdings.text: There is no law to prevent the State from prescribing the conditions of grants to private educational institutions by mere executive instructions which have not the force of statutory rules.

anchor.surface_text: Conditions of these grants may be prescribed by statutory rules there is however no law to prevent the State from prescribing the conditions of such grants by mere executive instructions which have not the force of statutory rules.

holdings.reasoning_summary: State discretion in grant conditions; executive instructions valid alternative to statutory rules for policy implementation like UGC pay scales.

holdings.text: Such conditions and instructions as to grant-in-aid confer no right on the teachers of the private colleges and they cannot ask that either a particular instruction or condition should be enforced or should not be enforced.

anchor.surface_text: Such conditions and instructions as to grant-in-aid confer no right on the teachers of the private colleges and they cannot ask that either a particular instruction or condition should be enforced or should not be enforced.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Admin instructions create obligations between State and college only; teachers lack vested rights; analogy to withholding grants as natural consequence.

holdings.text: Mere administrative instructions confer no right of any kind on teachers and they cannot apply to the High Court for a mandamus asking for the enforcement or non-enforcement of the rules, even if indirectly there may be some effect on them.

anchor.surface_text: The rules for the purpose of grant-in-aid being-as in this case-merely executive instructions confer no right of any kind on teachers and they cannot apply to the High Court for a mandamus asking for the enforcement or non-enforcement of the rules,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Precedent from Raman & Raman v. State of Madras: executive orders lack status of law, no vested rights arise; applies directly as Rules not statutory.

holdings.text: The Rules being mere administrative instructions are matters between private colleges and the Government in the matter of grant-in-aid to such colleges, and no teacher of a college has any right under the Rules to ask either for their enforcement or for their non-enforcement.
holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court finding not disputed; genesis shows consultative framing as grant conditions, not statutory under Gauhati Act or amendment.

holdings.text: The Court cannot interfere with the order of the High Court insofar as it is against the Governing Body of the College as there is no appeal by the College.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Procedural bar: no appellant from that part of order; special leave appeal limited.

holdings.text: We should not be taken to have approved of the order of the High Court against the Governing Body of the College in circumstances like the present.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Express disclaimer on undecided issue of writ against non-statutory body; reserves for future.

precedents.citation: Messrs. Raman and Raman The State of Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: We may in this connection refer to Messrs. Raman and Raman The State of Madras 1 where this Court had to consider certain orders and directions issued under s. 43A of the Motor Vehicles  Madras Amendment  Act, 1948.

precedents.case_name: Raman and Raman v. State of Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: Orders issued under s. 43A of the Motor Vehicles (Madras Amendment) Act, 1948 did not have the status of law regulating rights of parties but were administrative orders from which no rights, much less vested rights, arise.
precedents.cited_holding: such orders did not have the status of law regulating the rights of parties and must partake of the character of administrative orders. It was further held that there could be no right arising out of mere executive instructions, much less a vested right

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the High Court was in error when it granted a writ against the State through the Director, by which the Director was asked not to give effect to its letter dated March 20, 1962, against the Governing Body of the College. Then we come to the question whether a writ could have been issued against the Governing Body of the College. We find

outcome.relief_summary: High Court order set aside insofar as it issued writ/mandamus against the State/Director directing them not to give effect to letter dated March 20, 1962; no interference with High Court order against Governing Body of the College as no appeal filed by it
directions: Court clarifies it does not approve High Court order against Governing Body but refrains from interfering due to absence of appeal by College
